count.description: Return the number of rows matching the query (COUNT(*) counts rows; COUNT(expr) counts non-NULL expr values).

max.description: Return the maximum value in the given column.

min.description: Return the minimum value in the given column.

avg.description: Return the average (arithmetic mean) of non-NULL values in the column.

sum.description: Return the sum of non-NULL numeric values in the column.

abs.description: Return the absolute value of x.

ceil.description: Return the smallest integer greater than or equal to x.

floor.description: Return the largest integer less than or equal to x.

round.description: Round x to n decimal places (n defaults to 0).

trunc.description: Truncate x to n decimal places (n defaults to 0); for dates, TRUNC(date[, fmt]) truncates to the specified date precision.

mod.description: Return remainder of x divided by y.

power.description: Return x raised to the power y.

sqrt.description: Return the square root of x.

exp.description: Return e raised to the power x (natural exponential).

ln.description: Return the natural logarithm (base e) of x.

log.description: Return the logarithm of x with base b.

greatest.description: Return the greatest (highest) value from the list of expressions, considering datatype ordering.

least.description: Return the least (smallest) value from the list of expressions.

concat.description: Concatenate two strings (CONCAT accepts two arguments; '||' operator supports multiple).
concat.example: SELECT CONCAT('data', 'base') FROM dual; -- or SELECT 'data' || 'base' FROM dual;

substr.description: Return substring of str starting at position start for length characters (length optional).

instr.description: Return the position of the (occurrence-th) occurrence of substr within str, searching from start.

length.description: Return the length (number of characters) of str.

initcap.description: Return str with the first letter of each word in uppercase and the rest in lowercase.
initcap.example: SELECT INITCAP('oracle database tips') FROM dual;

replace.description: Replace occurrences of search_str in str with replace_str (replace_str optional).

translate.description: Replace characters in str that appear in from_str with corresponding characters in to_str (1:1 mapping).

lpad.description: Left-pad str to the specified length with pad_str (default space).

rpad.description: Right-pad str to the specified length with pad_str (default space).

ltrim.description: Trim characters in set (default whitespace) from the left of str.

rtrim.description: Trim characters in set (default whitespace) from the right of str.

trim.description: Trim trim_char (or whitespace) from str on the specified side (LEADING/TRAILING/BOTH).

chr.description: Return the character having the binary equivalent to n (ASCII/character set code).
chr.example: SELECT CHR(79) || CHR(82) || CHR(65) FROM dual;

ascii.description: Return the numeric code (ASCII/character set) of the first character.

dump.description: Return a string showing the internal datatype code, length, and internal representation of expr.

nvl.description: If expr1 is NULL, return expr2; otherwise return expr1.

nvl2.description: If expr1 is NOT NULL return expr_if_not_null, else return expr_if_null.
nvl2.example: SELECT NVL2(manager_id, 'has manager', 'no manager') FROM employees;

nullif.description: Return NULL if expr1 = expr2; otherwise return expr1.

coalesce.description: Return the first non-NULL expression from the list.

decode.function_signature: DECODE(expr, search1, result1, search2, result2, ..., default)
decode.description: Compare expr to each search value; return the corresponding result on match, otherwise default. (Oracle-specific convenience similar to CASE.)

to_char.description: Convert a date or number to a string using the optional format fmt.

to_date.description: Convert string to DATE using the specified format.

to_number.description: Convert string to NUMBER using optional format.

add_months.description: Return date plus n months; if the resulting month has fewer days and the original day is too large, result is last day of month.

months_between.description: Return number of months (and fractional months) between date1 and date2.

next_day.description: Return the date of the next weekday named char_day after date.

last_day.description: Return the last day of the month that contains date.

sysdate.description: Pseudocolumn returning the current date and time from the database server (DATE datatype).

current_date.description: Return the current date in the session time zone (DATE datatype).
current_date.example_result: current date/time in session time zone

sin.description: Return the sine of x (x in radians).

cos.description: Return the cosine of x (x in radians).

tan.description: Return the tangent of x (x in radians).

asin.description: Return the arc sine of x (result in radians).

acos.description: Return the arc cosine of x (result in radians).

atan.description: Return the arc tangent of x (result in radians).

atan2.description: Return the arc tangent of y/x using the signs of both arguments to determine the quadrant of the return value.

sinh.description: Return the hyperbolic sine of x.

cosh.description: Return the hyperbolic cosine of x.

tanh.description: Return the hyperbolic tangent of x.

cot.description: Return the cotangent of x (1 / TAN(x)).

sign.description: Return -1 if x < 0, 0 if x = 0, 1 if x > 0.

standard_hash.description: Compute a cryptographic hash (SHA1/MD5/SHA256/etc.) of expr; default algorithm depends on Oracle version.

ora_hash.description: Return a hash value for expr (non-cryptographic) useful for partitioning or bucketing.

systimestamp.description: Return the current timestamp with time zone of the database server (TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE).

localtimestamp.description: Return the current timestamp in the session time zone (TIMESTAMP without time zone).

current_timestamp.description: Return the current date and time in the session time zone as TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE.

sessiontimezone.description: Return the session time zone (as a character value).

to_timestamp.description: Convert a string to a TIMESTAMP using the given format model.

to_timestamp_tz.description: Convert a string to a TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE using the format model.
to_timestamp_tz.example: SELECT TO_TIMESTAMP_TZ('2025-10-26 12:00:00 +02:00','YYYY-MM-DD HH24:MI:SS TZH:TZM') FROM dual;

from_tz.description: Convert a TIMESTAMP value to TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE by adding the specified time zone.

extract.description: Extract a component (YEAR, MONTH, DAY, HOUR, MINUTE, SECOND) from a date or timestamp value.
extract.example: SELECT EXTRACT(YEAR FROM TO_DATE('2025-10-26','YYYY-MM-DD')) FROM dual;

numtodsinterval.description: Convert n (number) to an INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND using unit like 'DAY','HOUR','MINUTE','SECOND'.

numtoyminterval.description: Convert n (number) to an INTERVAL YEAR TO MONTH using unit 'YEAR' or 'MONTH'.

scn_to_timestamp.description: Convert a system change number (SCN) to an approximate TIMESTAMP.

to_nchar.description: Convert an expression to NCHAR or NVARCHAR2 string using an optional format model.

to_binary_float.description: Convert an expression to the BINARY_FLOAT data type.

to_binary_double.description: Convert an expression to the BINARY_DOUBLE data type.

convert.description: Convert a string to another character set.

to_single_byte.description: Convert multi-byte characters in str to their single-byte equivalents (useful for East-Asian charsets).

to_multi_byte.description: Convert single-byte characters in str to their multi-byte equivalents.

nlssort.description: Return a sort key for str using the specified NLS sorting parameters (useful in ORDER BY).

regexp_instr.function_signature: REGEXP_INSTR(source, pattern [, start [, nth [, return_option [, match_parameter]]]])
regexp_instr.description: Return the position of a regular-expression match in source (powerful regex search).

regexp_substr.description: Return the substring matching the regular-expression pattern.

regexp_replace.function_signature: REGEXP_REPLACE(source, pattern, replace_string [, start [, nth [, match_parameter]]])
regexp_replace.description: Replace substrings that match a regular-expression pattern.

regexp_count.description: Return the number of occurrences of the regular-expression pattern in source.

json_value.function_signature: JSON_VALUE(json_column, 'json_path' RETURNING datatype DEFAULT return_on_error ON ERROR)
json_value.description: Extract a scalar value from a JSON document using a SQL/JSON path expression.

json_query.description: Extract an object or array from a JSON document as JSON text.

json_table.description: Project JSON data into rows and columns (table-like view of JSON).
json_table.example: SELECT * FROM JSON_TABLE('[{"id":1}]','$[*]' COLUMNS (id PATH '$.id')) jt;

json_exists.description: Return true if the specified JSON path exists in the JSON document.

json_objectagg.description: Aggregate function to produce a single JSON object from key-value pairs.
json_objectagg.example: SELECT JSON_OBJECTAGG(k VALUE v) FROM (SELECT 'a' k, 1 v FROM dual);

json_arrayagg.description: Aggregate function to produce a JSON array from expression values.
json_arrayagg.example: SELECT JSON_ARRAYAGG(val) FROM (SELECT 1 val FROM dual UNION ALL SELECT 2 FROM dual);

xmltype.description: Construct an XMLType instance from an XML string or CLOB.

xmlcast.description: Cast an XML expression to an Oracle SQL datatype.

xmlserialize.description: Serialize XMLType content to a character large object (CLOB) or VARCHAR2.
xmlserialize.example: SELECT XMLSERIALIZE(CONTENT XMLTYPE('1') AS CLOB) FROM dual;

xmlquery.description: Evaluate an XQuery expression against XML data and return XML results.
xmlquery.example: SELECT XMLQUERY('/a' PASSING XMLTYPE('1')) FROM dual;

xmlagg.description: Aggregate XML fragments into a single XMLType.
xmlagg.example: SELECT XMLAGG(XMLELEMENT("e",col)) FROM (SELECT 'x' col FROM dual UNION ALL SELECT 'y' FROM dual);

xmltable.description: Project XML data into relational rows/columns (similar to JSON_TABLE but for XML).
xmltable.example: SELECT x.* FROM XMLTABLE('/items/item' PASSING XMLTYPE('<items><item>1</item></items>') COLUMNS val PATH '.') x;

sys_connect_by_path.description: Return the path (concatenated string) from a root row to the current row in a hierarchical query.
sys_connect_by_path.example: SELECT SYS_CONNECT_BY_PATH(name,'/') FROM emp CONNECT BY PRIOR empno = mgr;

connect_by_root.description: Return the root value of expr for the current row in a hierarchical query.
connect_by_root.example: SELECT CONNECT_BY_ROOT deptno FROM emp CONNECT BY PRIOR empno = mgr;

row_number.description: Analytic function that assigns a unique sequential integer to rows within a result partition.
row_number.example: SELECT ROW_NUMBER() OVER (ORDER BY salary DESC) rn, empno FROM emp;

rank.description: Analytic ranking function that assigns the rank of a row within a partition with gaps for ties.
rank.example: SELECT RANK() OVER (ORDER BY salary DESC) rnk FROM emp;

dense_rank.description: Analytic ranking function that assigns ranks without gaps for tied values.
dense_rank.example: SELECT DENSE_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY salary DESC) dr FROM emp;

ntile.description: Analytic function that distributes rows into n approximately equal buckets and returns the bucket number.
ntile.example: SELECT NTILE(4) OVER (ORDER BY salary) bucket FROM emp;

lag.description: Analytic function returning the value of expr from a preceding row.
lag.example: SELECT LAG(salary,1) OVER (ORDER BY empno) prev_salary FROM emp;

lead.description: Analytic function returning the value of expr from a following row.
lead.example: SELECT LEAD(salary,1) OVER (ORDER BY empno) next_salary FROM emp;

first_value.description: Analytic function returning the first value in an ordered set.
first_value.example: SELECT FIRST_VALUE(salary) OVER (ORDER BY salary DESC) top_salary FROM emp;

last_value.function_signature: LAST_VALUE(expr) OVER (ORDER BY ... RANGE BETWEEN UNBOUNDED PRECEDING AND UNBOUNDED FOLLOWING)
last_value.description: Analytic function returning the last value in an ordered set (careful with frame clauses).
last_value.example: SELECT LAST_VALUE(salary) OVER (ORDER BY salary) last_sal FROM emp;

cume_dist.description: Analytic function returning the cumulative distribution of a value within a partition.
cume_dist.example: SELECT CUME_DIST() OVER (ORDER BY salary) cd FROM emp;

percent_rank.description: Analytic function that returns the relative rank of a row - (rank-1)/(n-1).
percent_rank.example: SELECT PERCENT_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY salary) pr FROM emp;

nth_value.description: Analytic function returning the nth value in the ordered set.
nth_value.example: SELECT NTH_VALUE(salary,2) OVER (ORDER BY salary) val FROM emp;

median.description: Aggregate function returning the median of expr values.

listagg.description: Aggregate function concatenating values from multiple rows into a single string.
listagg.example: SELECT LISTAGG(name, ',') WITHIN GROUP (ORDER BY name) FROM dept;

collect.description: Aggregate function that returns a collection (nested table) of expr values.
collect.example: SELECT CAST(COLLECT(empno) AS SYS.OdciNumberList) FROM emp;

corr.description: Aggregate function returning the Pearson correlation coefficient between x and y.

covar_pop.description: Aggregate function returning population covariance of x and y.

covar_samp.description: Aggregate function returning sample covariance of x and y.

regr_slope.description: Return the slope of the regression line for y on x.

regr_intercept.description: Return the intercept of the regression line for y on x.

regr_count.description: Return the number of non-null paired (y,x) values used in regression.

regr_r2.description: Return the coefficient of determination (R-squared) for regression of y on x.

regr_avgx.description: Return average of the independent variable x used in regression.

regr_avgy.description: Return average of the dependent variable y used in regression.

regr_sxx.description: Return sum of squares of x about its mean used in regression.

regr_syy.description: Return sum of squares of y about its mean used in regression.

regr_sxy.description: Return sum of cross-products of x and y about their means used in regression.

stddev.description: Return the sample standard deviation of expr (aggregate).

stddev_pop.description: Return the population standard deviation of expr.

stddev_samp.description: Return the sample standard deviation of expr (identical to STDDEV).

var_pop.description: Return the population variance of expr.

var_samp.description: Return the sample variance of expr.

variance.description: Return the sample variance of expr (synonym of VAR_SAMP in many contexts).

percentile_cont.description: Inverse distribution function that returns a continuous percentile value.
percentile_cont.example: SELECT PERCENTILE_CONT(0.5) WITHIN GROUP (ORDER BY salary) FROM emp;

percentile_disc.description: Inverse distribution function that returns a discrete percentile (one of the values).
percentile_disc.example: SELECT PERCENTILE_DISC(0.5) WITHIN GROUP (ORDER BY salary) FROM emp;

hextoraw.description: Convert a hexadecimal string to a RAW value.

rawtohex.description: Convert RAW value to its hexadecimal representation.

bitand.description: Return the bitwise AND of two numbers.

to_clob.description: Convert a character expression to CLOB.

user.description: Return the current Oracle username (pseudocolumn / function-like).

current_user.description: Return the current SQL user (same as USER in many contexts).

sys_context.description: Return the value of environment or context parameters (useful for session/application context).

dbms_random_value.description: Return a pseudo-random number (package function DBMS_RANDOM.VALUE).

soundex.description: Return the SOUNDEX code for str (phonetic representation).

to_char_from_number_formats_note.description: TO_CHAR supports extensive number and date format models (see TO_CHAR entry previously provided).

lengthb.description: Return the length of str in bytes (not characters).

lengthc.description: Return the length of str in characters considering multibyte semantics (character count).

instrb.description: Return position of substr in str measured in bytes.

to_lob.description: Convert long (deprecated) datatype to LOB (used in certain migration contexts).

sysdate_related_functions_note.description: Functions like SYSDATE, CURRENT_DATE were listed earlier; Oracle also supports many DATE/TIMESTAMP conversion utilities (TO_DATE, TO_CHAR, EXTRACT etc.).

cast.description: Standard SQL function to convert expr to a target SQL datatype.
cast.example: SELECT CAST('123' AS NUMBER) FROM dual;

to_raw.description: Convert values to RAW in contexts where supported (usage can vary by version).

rowidtochar.description: Return the CHAR representation of a ROWID.
rowidtochar.example: SELECT ROWIDTOCHAR(ROWID) FROM emp WHERE ROWNUM=1;

rowidtonumber.description: Return the numeric representation of a ROWID (version-dependent).
rowidtonumber.example: SELECT ROWIDTONUM(ROWID) FROM emp WHERE ROWNUM=1;

ora_rowid.description: Pseudocolumn / function returning the ROWID of the row (useful in SELECT lists).
ora_rowid.example: SELECT ORA_ROWID FROM emp WHERE ROWNUM=1;

dbms_lob_getlength.description: Return the length (in bytes or characters depending on LOB) of a LOB. (call via package DBMS_LOB).
dbms_lob_getlength.example: SELECT DBMS_LOB.GETLENGTH(clob_col) FROM t WHERE id=1;

dbms_lob_substr.description: Return a substring of a LOB (package DBMS_LOB function).
dbms_lob_substr.example: SELECT DBMS_LOB.SUBSTR(clob_col, 100, 1) FROM t WHERE id=1;

userenv.description: Return user environment information (older interface; SYS_CONTEXT is recommended).

nvl2_variation_note.description: NVL2 already listed earlier; related functions NULLIF and COALESCE are also already present.

tz_offset.description: Return the offset of a time zone region as a string (+HH:MI).

cardinality.description: Return the number of elements in a collection (VARRAY/NESTED TABLE).
cardinality.example: SELECT CARDINALITY(CAST(MULTISET(SELECT empno FROM emp) AS SYS.OdciNumberList)) FROM dual;

json_mergepatch.description: Return a merged JSON document following JSON Merge Patch semantics (available in recent Oracle releases).

xml_exists.description: Return TRUE if the XPath expression exists in the given XML source.
xml_exists.example: SELECT XMLExists('/a' PASSING XMLTYPE('1')) FROM dual;

regexp_like.description: Return TRUE if source matches the regular-expression pattern (can be used in WHERE).

instrc.description: Return the position (in characters) of substr in str considering character semantics (multibyte-safe).

substrc.description: Return substring in character semantics for multibyte strings.

instr2.description: Position of substr in str measured in UCS2 codepoints (version-dependent).
